column2: Polish: Borysław) is a city located on the Tysmenytsia River (a tributary of the Dniester)
column3: in Lviv Oblast (region) of western Ukraine. Boryslav is designated as a city of oblast significance. It is a major center of petroleum industry. Population: 34

column1: The area of the modern town of Boryslav has been inhabited at least since the Bronze Age. There are remnants of a pagan shrine from the 1st millennium BC located in the area
column3: mostly depicting solar signs – symbols of a pre-Christian Solar deity. Between the 9th and 13th centuries
column4: the site of the modern town housed a fortress named Tustan
column5: which was part of a belt of similar strongholds defending the Kievan Rus' from the west and south. After the dissolution of Kievan Rus'
column6: the town became a part of the Halych-Volhynian Principality. With the collapse of the latter
column7: in the 14th century Boryslav became a part of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland. It was first mentioned in a document from 19 March 1387
column8: listing all personal belongings of Queen regnant Jadwiga of Poland.Since that time
column11: was a small town related to the nearby metropolis of Lwów (currently Lviv
column12: Ukraine) and mostly shared its fate. In 1772
column14: it was annexed by Austria and became a part of the Austrian Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria. One of the great technological developments of the 19th century was the discovery by pharmacist Johan (Jan) Zeh (uk:Зег Ян) (1817–1897
column15: in nearby Lviv) of technology that led to the establishment of a new industry based on petroleum. Scientists worked out a method of distilling Boryslaw crude oil
column16: and on 30 March 1853 made the first kerosene lamp. As early as 31 July 1853 their new lamp was used to illuminate the Public Hospital in Lviv. Their discoveries marked the beginnings of the rapid search for petroleum in the Carpathians — especially in the eastern sector of the mountain chain where rich oil deposits were discovered. In 1854 the first ozokerite mine was started in the town after the ore was discovered by Robert Doms. In the second half of 1853

column19: the town and its surroundings saw the emergence of an oil industry. One of the first oil rigs in the world was built near Boryslav by Robert Doms in 1861. The number of oil rigs also rose from 4
column21: 000 three years later. The oil boom drew many industry moguls from all over Austria-Hungary and many fortunes were earned and lost there. A period of prosperity saw the city's population grew as almost 10

column31: 000 tonnes of oil were produced in the region — roughly 5% of the world's oil production at that time making the region the third biggest producer of oil after the US and the Russian Empire in the world.

column1: After the Great War the area became part of the new West Ukrainian People's Republic. After the Polish-Ukrainian War of November 1918 – July 1919 the area became part of the newly-reborn Poland. In 1920 the mining school was significantly expanded and was renamed to Carpathian Geological Station
column2: a de facto oil mining university. As the capital of the Zagłębie Borysławskie (Borysław Oil Basin)
column3: the town of Borysław was the centre of then Polish oil and ozokerite extraction industries and one of the most important industrial zones of Poland. Because of that
column6: the town was granted a city charter. Together with the nearby settlement of Tustanowice (Tustanovychi

column1: After the 1939 Soviet invasion of Poland
column2: the town was annexed by the Soviet Union under the terms of the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact. It was allocated to the Ukrainian SSR and renamed Boryslav. In 1941
column3: the city fell under German control upon the advances of the German army to the east at the start of Soviet–German hostilities.

column1: Following Germany's defeat in World War II
column2: the town came again under the Soviet rule. Since 1991 the town has been part of an independent Ukraine. The oil industry remains operating. Experts believe that potential oil fields around Boryslav contain far more stocks.
